article.headline: A 10% selloff in the stock market is most likely, says expert who called March lows: âSomething has to giveâ
article.body: Michael Wilson, chief U.S. equity strategist at Morgan Stanley, and his colleagues believe that the narrow breadth of winners in the stock market will likely result in a 10% correction before giving way to a renewed rally. The analysts, in a Monday research report, say that either a host of risks that are building beneath the surface of the marketsâ unimpeded uptrend â spiking COVID-19 cases, 2020 presidential election uncertainty and nearly unchecked government spending â must be cured or the recent technology-related winners need to fall along with the rest of the market. âWe think the most likely outcome remains a 10% correction in the broader index led by the beneficiaries before the recovery and bull market continues,â wrote Wilson and strategists Adam Virgadamo, Andrew Pauker and Michelle Weaver. The report comes as the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.39% finished the session up 1.5% to post its 29th all-time closing high of 2020. The index is up nearly 60% from its March 23 low, powered by a handful of large-capitalization companies, including Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.48% and Tesla TSLA, +1.89%, as well as from the so-called FAANG names, Facebook Inc. FB, +0.26%, Apple Inc. AAPL, +1.74%, Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +3.01%, Netflix NFLX, +1.43% and Google parent Alphabet Inc. GOOG, +1.97% GOOGL, +1.82% The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% and the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% are both up by at least 43% since their late-March nadirs, but that pace isnât as brisk as the Nasdaq because of the latterâs proportion of tech-related shares. Wilsonâs picks havenât always been correct, but he and his team did call for markets to bottom on March 16, just a week before the S&P 500 hit its recent low 2,237 on March 23, arguing at that time that the COVID-19 epidemic and simultaneous crash in oil prices were simply the âfinal blows to an already exhausted U.S. expansion.â Wilson advocated for buying during a May pullback, which also seems to have been a good call as stock markets have posted four consecutive monthly gains since March.
